p: Viral infections, primarily from rotavirus, cause 75–90 % of infectious diarrhea cases in the industrialized world. Bacterial pathogens cause another 10–20 % of cases, with as many as 10 % of these occurring secondary to enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (e.g., traveler’s diarrhea). Parasites such as Giardia intestinalis and Cryptosporidium cause fewer than 5 % of cases [ 31]. In the United States, routine rotavirus vaccination has led to a 60–75 % reduction in pediatric rotavirus hospitalization since 2006. With the continued decline of rotavirus-associated gastroenteritis, noroviruses (Norwalk-like viruses) have become the leading cause of medically attended acute gastroenteritis in children younger than 5 years in that country [ 32].
